civilopediaText.text: Heroes manage their own food supplies and must keep their armies fed during campaigns and expeditions.
⁂ Hero Food Storage
Each hero has their own food supply that they carry with them:
• Heroes start with a limited amount of ⁂ food
• Food can be replenished by visiting castles and cities
• Heroes can carry enough food for several turns of campaigning
⁂ Army Consumption
When heroes are on campaign, their armies consume food each turn:
• Larger armies require more ⁂ food per turn
• Different unit types may have different food requirements
• When food runs out, army units will start to desert
• Desertion can cause significant losses to army strength
Cities and garrisons provide crucial support for heroes and their armies through food and defensive bonuses.
◉ City Garrisons
When heroes are stationed in cities as garrisons:
• The city's ◉ population supports the hero's army
• No ⁂ food consumption from hero's personal supply
• Army units heal faster while in garrison
• Heroes can replenish their ⁂ food stores while garrisoned
† Defensive Benefits
Garrisoned heroes provide significant defensive advantages:
• Enhanced city † defense strength
• Protection against sieges and raids
• Faster response to nearby threats
• Reduced ¤ gold upkeep costs for stationed units
Some special units can sustain themselves without relying on external food supplies or city support.
⁂ Foraging Units
Certain unit types have the ability to find their own food:
• Scout units can forage for ⁂ food in wilderness
• Some barbarian units are naturally self-sufficient
• Naval units may fish or raid for supplies
• These units don't drain the hero's food reserves
⚙ Supply Lines
Advanced civilizations can establish supply networks:
• Roads and trade routes can extend supply lines
• Heroes within supply range consume less ⁂ food
• Breaking enemy supply lines can cause starvation
• Merchants and supply wagons can resupply field armies
